clinical_study.brief_title: Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) Guided Alveolar Recruitment Strategy
clinical_study.official_title: The Influence of a Functional Residual Capacity Guided Alveolar Recruitment Strategy After Open Endotracheal Suctioning on Oxygenation and Regional Ventilation

brief_summary.textblock: In ventilated patients open endotracheal suctioning may lead to alveolar derecruitment, which can be monitored by means of functional residual capacity (FRC) measurements. The investigators hypothesized that a recruitment strategy based on FRC measurements would improve oxygenation and regional ventilation after an open endotracheal suctioning manoeuvre.

detailed_description.textblock: In mechanically ventilated patients the functional residual capacity will be measured before (baseline) and after an open endotracheal suctioning manoeuvre. Based on these changes patients will be divided into two groups: Group A with more than 94% of baseline FRC, and Group B with less than 94% of baseline FRC. Both groups will be randomized to receive an alveolar recruitment manoeuvre or no alveolar recruitment manoeuvre, leading to four groups. Oxygenation and regional ventilation with electrical impedance tomography will be studied.

intervention.description: Increase airway pressure during pressure controlled ventilation up to peak-airway pressure of 40 cmH20 and PEEP of 15 cmH20.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ventilated after elective cardiac surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- hemodynamic instability (eg. intraaortic balloon pump)
- acute lung injury, i.e. PEEP > 10cmH20 or FiO2 > 0.4
